text: ਜਬ ਨਖ ਸਿਖ ਇਹੁ ਮਨੁ ਚੀਨ੍ਹਾ ॥
section: Ramkali - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: When I came to understand this mind, from the tips of my toes to the crown of my head,

transliteration.text: jab nakh sikh ih man chīnhā .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

author.author: Saint Kabir
author.description:
Saint Kabir [1440 - 1518] was a Muslim mystic born in Varanasi in India, whose 541 hymns are included in the Guru Granth Sahib. His writings about God are full of love and devotion, very direct and striking in appeal.

The birth of Kabir remains to this day shrouded in mystery and legend. Authorities disagree on both when he was born and who his parents were. One legend proclaims a divine virginal birth. His mother was reputed to have been of the Brahman caste and to have become pregnant after a visit to a Hindu shrine.

Because she was unwed, she abandoned Kabir, who was found and adopted by a Muslim weaver. That his early life began as a Muslim there is no doubt, although he later became influenced by the Hindu ascetic, Ramananda, who he accepted as his Guru.

section: Ramkali - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: then I took my cleansing bath, deep within my self. ||1||

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

text: ਨਹੀ ਮਿਰਤੁ ਨ ਜਨਮੁ ਜਰਾ ॥੧॥ ਰਹਾਉ ॥
section: Ramkali - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: There is no death, no re-birth, and no aging for me now. ||1||Pause||

transliteration.text: nahī mirat n janam jarā .1. rahāu .

text: ਦੁਨੀਆ ਹੁਸੀਆਰ ਬੇਦਾਰ ਜਾਗਤ ਮੁਸੀਅਤ ਹਉ ਰੇ ਭਾਈ ॥
section: Ramkali - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: People of the world, remain awake and aware. Even though you are awake, you are being robbed, O Siblings of Destiny.

transliteration.text: dunīā husīār bēdār jāgat musīat hau rē bhāī .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

text: ਨਿਗਮ ਹੁਸੀਆਰ ਪਹਰੂਆ ਦੇਖਤ ਜਮੁ ਲੇ ਜਾਈ ॥੧॥ ਰਹਾਉ ॥
section: Ramkali - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: While the Vedas stand guard watching, the Messenger of Death carries you away. ||1||Pause||

transliteration.text: nigam husīār paharūā dēkhat jam lē jāī .1. rahāu .

author.description:
Saint Kabir [1440 - 1518] was a Muslim mystic born in Varanasi in India, whose 541 hymns are included in the Guru Granth Sahib. His writings about God are full of love and devotion, very direct and striking in appeal.

The birth of Kabir remains to this day shrouded in mystery and legend. Authorities disagree on both when he was born and who his parents were. One legend proclaims a divine virginal birth. His mother was reputed to have been of the Brahman caste and to have become pregnant after a visit to a Hindu shrine.

Because she was unwed, she abandoned Kabir, who was found and adopted by a Muslim weaver. That his early life began as a Muslim there is no doubt, although he later became influenced by the Hindu ascetic, Ramananda, who he accepted as his Guru.

text: ਨੀੰਬੁ ਭਇਓ ਆਂਬੁ ਆਂਬੁ ਭਇਓ ਨੀੰਬਾ ਕੇਲਾ ਪਾਕਾ ਝਾਰਿ ॥
section: Ramkali - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: He thinks that the bitter nimm fruit is a mango, and the mango is a bitter nimm. He imagines the ripe banana on the thorny bush.

transliteration.text: nīnb bhaiō ānhb ānhb bhaiō nīnbā kēlā pākā jhār .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

author.author: Saint Kabir
author.description:

The birth of Kabir remains to this day shrouded in mystery and legend. Authorities disagree on both when he was born and who his parents were. One legend proclaims a divine virginal birth. His mother was reputed to have been of the Brahman caste and to have become pregnant after a visit to a Hindu shrine.

Because she was unwed, she abandoned Kabir, who was found and adopted by a Muslim weaver. That his early life began as a Muslim there is no doubt, although he later became influenced by the Hindu ascetic, Ramananda, who he accepted as his Guru.

text: ਨਾਲੀਏਰ ਫਲੁ ਸੇਬਰਿ ਪਾਕਾ ਮੂਰਖ ਮੁਗਧ ਗਵਾਰ ॥੧॥
section: Ramkali - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: He thinks that the ripe coconut hangs on the barren simmal tree; what a stupid, idiotic fool he is! ||1||

transliteration.text: nālīēr phal sēbar pākā mūrakh mugadh gavār .1.

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

author.author: Saint Kabir
author.description:

text: ਹਰਿ ਭਇਓ ਖਾਂਡੁ ਰੇਤੁ ਮਹਿ ਬਿਖਰਿਓ ਹਸਤੀੰ ਚੁਨਿਓ ਨ ਜਾਈ ॥
section: Ramkali - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: The Lord is like sugar, spilled onto the sand; the elephant cannot pick it up.

transliteration.text: har bhaiō khānhd rēt mah bikhariō hasatīn chuniō n jāī .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

The birth of Kabir remains to this day shrouded in mystery and legend. Authorities disagree on both when he was born and who his parents were. One legend proclaims a divine virginal birth. text: ਕਹਿ ਕਮੀਰ ਕੁਲ ਜਾਤਿ ਪਾਂਤਿ ਤਜਿ ਚੀਟੀ ਹੋਇ ਚੁਨਿ ਖਾਈ ॥੨॥੩॥੧੨॥
section: Ramkali - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: Says Kabeer, give up your ancestry, social status and honor; be like the tiny ant - pick up and eat the sugar. ||2||3||12||

transliteration.text: kah kamīr kul jāt pānht taj chītī hōi chun khāī .2.3.12.

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

text: ਬਾਣੀ ਨਾਮਦੇਉ ਜੀਉ ਕੀ ਰਾਮਕਲੀ ਘਰੁ ੧
section: Ramkali - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: The Word Of Naam Dayv Jee, Raamkalee, First House:

transliteration.text: bānī nāmadēu jīu kī rāmakalī ghar 1

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: None
author.description: There is no author associated with this line, as it may be the preamble to the hymn

section: Ramkali - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: One Universal Creator God. By The Grace Of The True Guru:

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: None
author.description: There is no author associated with this line, as it may be the preamble to the hymn

text: ਆਨੀਲੇ ਕਾਗਦੁ ਕਾਟੀਲੇ ਗੂਡੀ ਆਕਾਸ ਮਧੇ ਭਰਮੀਅਲੇ ॥
section: Ramkali - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: The boy takes paper, cuts it and makes a kite, and flies it in the sky.

transliteration.text: ānīlē kāgad kātīlē gūdī ākās madhē bharamīalē .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

author.author: Saint Namdev
author.description:
Saint Namdev [1270 - 1350] was born in the state of Maharashtra village of Naras-Vamani, in Satara district (presently called Narsi Namdev). His father was called Damshet, a tailor, and his mother was called Gonabai.

The main spiritual message of Saint Namdev, just like the Sikh Gurus, was to emphasise the importance of living a married householder life and that through marriage, living in the world and meditating on God, one could attain enlightenment. Sixty-one of his hymns are included in the Guru Granth Sahib. He was also a close friend of Saint Trilochan.

text: ਪੰਚ ਜਨਾ ਸਿਉ ਬਾਤ ਬਤਊਆ ਚੀਤੁ ਸੁ ਡੋਰੀ ਰਾਖੀਅਲੇ ॥੧॥
section: Ramkali - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: Talking with his friends, he still keeps his attention on the kite string. ||1||

transliteration.text: panch janā siu bāt bataūā chīt s dōrī rākhīalē .1.

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

section: Ramkali - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: My mind has been pierced by the Name of the Lord,

text: ਜੈਸੇ ਕਨਿਕ ਕਲਾ ਚਿਤੁ ਮਾਂਡੀਅਲੇ ॥੧॥ ਰਹਾਉ ॥
section: Ramkali - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: like the goldsmith, whose attention is held by his work. ||1||Pause||

transliteration.text: jaisē kanik kalā chit mānhdīalē .1. rahāu .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. text: ਆਨੀਲੇ ਕੁੰਭੁ ਭਰਾਈਲੇ ਊਦਕ ਰਾਜ ਕੁਆਰਿ ਪੁਰੰਦਰੀਏ ॥
section: Ramkali - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: The young girl in the city takes a pitcher, and fills it with water.

transliteration.text: ānīlē kunbh bharāīlē ūdak rāj kuār purandarīē .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

text: ਹਸਤ ਬਿਨੋਦ ਬੀਚਾਰ ਕਰਤੀ ਹੈ ਚੀਤੁ ਸੁ ਗਾਗਰਿ ਰਾਖੀਅਲੇ ॥੨॥
section: Ramkali - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: She laughs, and plays, and talks with her friends, but she keeps her attention focused on the pitcher of water. ||2||

transliteration.text: hasat binōd bīchār karatī hai chīt s gāgar rākhīalē .2.

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

text: ਮੰਦਰੁ ਏਕੁ ਦੁਆਰ ਦਸ ਜਾ ਕੇ ਗਊ ਚਰਾਵਨ ਛਾਡੀਅਲੇ ॥
section: Ramkali - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: The cow is let loose, out of the mansion of the ten gates, to graze in the field.

transliteration.text: mandar ēk duār das jā kē gaū charāvan shādīalē .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

text: ਪਾਂਚ ਕੋਸ ਪਰ ਗਊ ਚਰਾਵਤ ਚੀਤੁ ਸੁ ਬਛਰਾ ਰਾਖੀਅਲੇ ॥੩॥
section: Ramkali - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: It grazes up to five miles away, but keeps its attention focused on its calf. ||3||

transliteration.text: pānhch kōs par gaū charāvat chīt s basharā rākhīalē .3.

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

text: ਕਹਤ ਨਾਮਦੇਉ ਸੁਨਹੁ ਤਿਲੋਚਨ ਬਾਲਕੁ ਪਾਲਨ ਪਉਢੀਅਲੇ ॥
section: Ramkali - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: Says Naam Dayv, listen, O Trilochan: the child is laid down in the cradle.

transliteration.text: kahat nāmadēu sunah tilōchan bālak pālan paudhīalē .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.

text: ਅੰਤਰਿ ਬਾਹਰਿ ਕਾਜ ਬਿਰੂਧੀ ਚੀਤੁ ਸੁ ਬਾਰਿਕ ਰਾਖੀਅਲੇ ॥੪॥੧॥
section: Ramkali - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: Its mother is at work, inside and outside, but she holds her child in her thoughts. ||4||1||

transliteration.text: antar bāhar kāj birūdhī chīt s bārik rākhīalē .4.1.

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. text: ਬੇਦ ਪੁਰਾਨ ਸਾਸਤ੍ਰ ਆਨੰਤਾ ਗੀਤ ਕਬਿਤ ਨ ਗਾਵਉਗੋ ॥
section: Ramkali - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: There are countless Vedas, Puraanas and Shaastras; I do not sing their songs and hymns.

transliteration.text: bēd purān sāsatr ānantā gīt kabit n gāvaugō .

melody.description: The emotions in Ramkali are like those of a wise teacher disciplining their student. The student is aware of the pain of learning, but is still conscious of the fact that ultimately it is for the best. In this way Ramkali conveys the change from all that we are familiar with, to something we are certain will be better.
